close_symbols: Any buffer-size macros/constants used by OS_NetworkGetHostName_Impl (e.g. OS_MAX_HOST_NAME_LEN)
Any standard <string.h> functions used by OS_NetworkGetHostName_Impl (e.g. strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, memcpy, memmove, memset, strlen, strspn)
explanation:
Why each symbol is needed:

- OS_CHECK_POINTER (macro/implementation): The target function calls this macro on host_name. Its behavior (does it return an error code, set return value, assert/abort, or do nothing) determines whether the subsequent host_name[0] write is reachable and whether a null/invalid pointer can be dereferenced. To decide bounds safety we must know its exact semantics/side-effects.

- OS_CHECK_SIZE (macro/implementation): The target function calls this macro on name_len. If this macro enforces name_len>0 or aborts on zero it prevents an out-of-bounds write to host_name[0]. If it does nothing, host_name[0] may be invalid when name_len==0. The macro implementation is required to assess that.

- OS_NetworkGetHostName_Impl (prototype and full implementation): The low-level implementation is delegated to for actually writing the name into the buffer. MISRA rule compliance depends primarily on whether that implementation uses any string.h functions and whether it respects the name_len bound and guarantees NUL-termination. The full source (or at least its contract and callees) is required to detect any strcpy/memcpy/strncpy/etc. usages that could write past name_len.

- OS_SUCCESS (macro/enum value): The target compares return_code against OS_SUCCESS and on failure performs host_name[0]=0. Knowing the numeric value is not strictly needed for bounds, but the definition clarifies return semantics and is useful when examining how the impl signals partial/failed writes versus success.

- int32 (typedef / definition): The return type used (int32) and its representation are relevant for understanding return values and macros that may be used by the CHECK macros or the impl. Include the typedef so the analyzer has the exact types used.

- size_t (typedef / header): name_len is size_t; having the definition/header ensures correct interpretation of signedness/width and interaction with checks and impl code (e.g., comparisons with 0, underflow, or conversions).

- Any buffer-size macros/constants used by OS_NetworkGetHostName_Impl (e.g. OS_MAX_HOST_NAME_LEN): The implementation may copy from or to buffers sized by compile-time constants. Those constants are needed to reason whether the impl can exceed the caller-supplied name_len or write beyond host_name bounds.

- Any standard <string.h> functions used by OS_NetworkGetHostName_Impl (e.g. strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, memcpy, memmove, memset, strlen, strspn): MISRA rule targets use of these functions. If the impl calls any of them, the analyzer must inspect the call sites (arguments, lengths) to determine whether they can cause out-of-bounds writes. Provide the exact usages from the impl so the analyzer can check correct length parameters and NUL-termination behavior.

Providing the above symbols (macro implementations, the low-level impl source, any size-related constants, and the exact standard library calls used) gives the necessary context to determine whether any string handling can write beyond the buffer bounds and thus violate the MISRA rule.
